frontmatter.title: Warthog Engine proxy (deprecated)
frontmatter.description: Configuring and running the Engine proxy

children.value: DEPRECATED: The engine proxy is not maintained, and to integrate with the Warthog platform's metrics, we recommend using Warthog Server's native reporting functionality. To integrate a non-Node server, take a look at our guide

properties.ariaLabel: background permalink

children.value: The Warthog Engine proxy is a small process that can be run in front of your GraphQL server. Its primary functions are:

information, to the Engine cloud service.

directive and configured to be either in-memory or shared through Memcache.
through a caching layer that can map query IDs to full query strings, allowing clients to send just query IDs over the wire.

(starting at Warthog Server 2.5) as built-in features, and using it allows you to forego running the proxy. The newest features in Warthog Engine are not supported in the Engine proxy and we recommend that all Node users use Warthog Server 2+ instead of running the proxy.
That said, the proxy is still a good option for getting set up with Engine in a few
You are not using Warthog Server, your server has an
plugin, and you want to get
You are not using Warthog Server and you want to use Warthog's

properties.ariaLabel: setup permalink

children.value: To get started with using Engine through the Engine proxy, you will need to:
Install a package in your GraphQL server that adds
data (in the Warthog Tracing format) to each request's response.
Configure and deploy the Engine proxy to run in front of your server using either Docker or npm.

properties.ariaLabel: instrument your server permalink

children.value: To get the performance metrics value out of Engine, you'll need to install a package in your server that adds the
GraphQL extension. If you want to set up response caching, you'll also need to install a package that adds the
If you're installing the Engine proxy
to set up automatic persisited queries, you can skip ahead to the
extensions are open specifications that can be implemented by any GraphQL server, and the following is a list of implementations:
natively supports tracing and cache control. See
for a more streamlined Node setup option.
Read the docs about using Warthog tracing.
You can test that you’ve correctly enabled Warthog Tracing by running any query against your API using GraphiQL.
field should now be returned as part of the response's
like below. Don’t worry, this data won’t make it back to your clients once you've set up the Engine proxy, because the proxy will filter it out.

properties.ariaLabel: get your api key permalink

children.value: and create a graph to get an API key. We’ll be using your new key in the next step.

properties.ariaLabel: run the proxy permalink

children.value: The proxy is a small process written in Go that you host and run inside your infrastructure. It's designed to allow all of your requests and responses to pass through normally while it collects trace data, caches results, and identifies persisted queries. It's designed to handle large volumes of traffic comfortably without overloading. It does not rely on accessing the Engine cloud service to run or perform caching functions, but if it cannot talk to the Engine cloud service it will not be able to report metrics.
Warthog distributes the Engine proxy in two forms: as an
. You can use any one of the following options for running the proxy, depending what works best for you and your team:
Run the proxy with Warthog Server
Run a standalone proxy using Node
Run a standalone proxy using Docker
Run the proxy through a Platform as a Service (eg. Heroku)
Run the proxy in a serverless environment (eg. Lambda)

properties.ariaLabel: option 1 running the proxy with warthog server permalink

children.value: Option 1: Running the proxy with Warthog Server
The two cases where you should be running the Engine proxy with Warthog Server are:
You are using Warthog Server 1 and want the Warthog platform features that Engine brings.
You are using Warthog Server >2 & <2.5+ and want full query caching using the Engine proxy.
If you're using Warthog Server but neither of these conditions apply to you, you should be using the built-in features of Warthog Server 2+ instead of the Engine proxy.
This section assumes you're running your GraphQL server with the
web server package for Node, but if you're using a different framework the steps will be similar.
constructor and create a new Engine instance. You'll need to replace
// Make sure that tracing and cacheControl are both enabled
// By setting this to "false", we avoid using Warthog Server 2's
// integrated metric reporting and fall-back to using the Warthog
// Engine Proxy (running separately) for metric collection.
// Initialize your Express app like usual
// All of your GraphQL middleware goes here
// Initialize engine with your API key. Alternatively,
// set the ENGINE_API_KEY environment variable when you
// Call engine.listen(...) instead of app.listen(port) as you usually would

Engine is now wrapping your endpoint and processing your GraphQL requests and responses like normal. If you call your endpoint again, your requests will be routed through the Engine proxy to your server and back. If everything is working, you will no longer see
data in your responses because your Engine proxy is filtering and processing that information for you.

properties.ariaLabel: option 2 running a standalone proxy using node permalink

children.value: Option 2: Running a standalone proxy using Node

Even if your GraphQL server is not implemented with Node, you may find it easier to run a tiny Node program in your hosting environment than to run a Docker container. If so, this proxy deployment option is for you.
API, which simply runs the Engine proxy with a given configuration.
Then write a small Node program that uses it, like so:
// Note: you can also provide this in the ENGINE_API_KEY environment variable.
// The URL that the proxy should use to connect to your GraphQL server.
// Tell the proxy which ports to listen to and which paths should
// be treated as GraphQL instead of transparently proxied as raw HTTP.
// Start the Proxy; crash on errors.
Every deployment has its unique needs and we provide a variety of configuration options to fulfill them. For more configuration options, please see the
is generally the same as the argument Node GraphQL users pass to
. The main differences are that you need to specify the origin's HTTP URL yourself with
are specified inside the constructor instead of as options to
If you run this program with Node, the proxy will start up and start accepting connections at
. It will forward all requests to your server, which you told it is running on
If you open up GraphiQL on

extension data is no longer in the result of your query. This is because Engine is consuming it! You can verify that everything is working correctly by checking the Engine UI for your new service and confirming that you see data in the Metrics section.

properties.ariaLabel: option 3 running a standalone proxy with docker permalink

children.value: Option 3: Running a standalone proxy with Docker

The Engine proxy is also distributed as a Docker image that you can deploy and manage separate from your server. It does not matter where you choose to deploy and manage your proxy, though it's more efficient if your proxy is located on the same machine or network as your GraphQL server.
The Docker container distribution of Engine proxy is configured using a JSON

Every deployment has its unique needs, and we provide a variety of configuration options to fulfill them. For example, if your origin GraphQL server is running in a virtual-hosted environment (e.g. Heroku, AWS), you may need to override the
header sent to HTTP origins. For more details and instruction on configuration options, please see the
As it is JSON file, all object keys must be quoted, and trailing commas and comments are not allowed. Any reference in our docs to options passed to
otherwise translates directly into the engine config file. Like with

, you need to specify your GraphQL server's origin http URL (or other origin type like Lambda) inside the config file, and you need to specify the frontend port and GraphQL paths inside the config file rather than separately (if you're not using the default values of
Next, make sure you have a working
and type the following lines in your shell:
to name Engine Proxy release versions, and we release version 1.2.3 under the tags
. If you want to pin to a precise version, use the
tag. If you'd like to take patch upgrades but not minor upgrades, use the
tag. If you'd like to take minor upgrades, use the
This will run the Engine Proxy via Docker, routing port 3000 inside the container to port 3000 outside the container. (You can also pass
to just allow the Proxy direct access to your host's network.)
The Proxy should start up and accept connections at
and forward all requests to your server at
(or wherever you have configured your app to serve GraphiQL) and run any query. You should no longer see the
data in the result since Engine is now consuming it! Checking the Engine UI for your service, you should see data from the request you sent via GraphiQL come through in the metrics tab.
You can find the complete documentation for Engine configuration options on the
page, and some commonly-used fields worth knowing about are described in the

properties.ariaLabel: option 4 running the proxy through a platform as a service eg heroku permalink

children.value: Option 4: Running the proxy through a Platform as a Service (eg. Heroku)

It may be most convenient for you to run and host the Engine proxy outside your app's deployment altogether. If that is the case, automatically running the proxy on a Platform as a Service like Heroku might be the easiest option for you.
We have an example repository with a guide for
running the Engine proxy on Heroku
that you can follow along in. Like running a
, you'll need to configure your proxy with an
For Virtual Hosted environments where the
is dynamically set in an environment variable named
option. If your environment uses a different environment variable, you can name it with the
option instead. For more details and instruction on configuration options, please see the

It does not matter where you choose to deploy and manage your Engine proxy. We've built this guide for Heroku because they have an easy deployment mechanism for Docker containers, but we run our own Engine proxy on Amazon's

properties.ariaLabel: option 5 running the proxy in a serverless environment eg lambda permalink

children.value: Option 5: Running the proxy in a serverless environment (eg. Lambda)
Last but not least, you may be wondering how to use Engine if you run your application in a serverless environment like Lamdba. If so, this is the guide for you!

The best option for using Engine if you're running in a serverless environment is to use Warthog Server 2+ and its built-in reporting mechanism. Running the Engine proxy in serverless environments is tricky because the
and needs to be run separately from your cloud function.
To use Engine when running in serverless environments, we will need to configure and deploy the Engine proxy as a standalone docker container that is
from your cloud function. The Engine proxy is stateful (it collects and aggregates your metrics across requests), and as such it should not be deployed with your cloud function, but separately.
The only available option for running the Engine proxy with cloud functions is to run the proxy in a standalone docker container. To do that, you can follow one of our guides here:
Run a standalone proxy using Node
Run a standalone proxy using Docker
Run the proxy through a Platform as a Service (eg. Heroku)
The proxy needs to be run separately from your function because it's responsible for capturing, aggregating, and sending to Engine the trace data from each Lamdba instance GraphQL response.
The main difference between setting up the proxy to work with cloud functions versus setting it up with a persistent server is in how you configure it. You'll want an
This example is for AWS Lambda specifically, for which we have a special
type. Other cloud functions are supported with the standard HTTP invocation, and for non-AWS cloud functions see
for instructions on settup up the Engine proxy as a standalone API gateway to your cloud function. For full configuration details see
The Engine proxy will invoke the Lambda function as if it was called from Amazon's
, and the function should return a value suitable for

If you've got a proxy running and successfully configured to talk to your cloud functions, then sending a request to it will invoke your function and return the response back to you. If everything is working, you should be able to visit the Metrics tab in the Engine UI and see data from the requests you're sending in the interface!

properties.ariaLabel: feature configuration permalink

children.value: The following proxy features require specific setup steps to get working.

properties.ariaLabel: automatic persisted queries apq permalink

children.value: Automatically persisting your queries is a performance technique in which you send a query hash to your server instead of the entire GraphQL query string. Your server keeps track of the map between these hashes and their full query strings and does the lookup on its end, saving you the bandwidth of sending the full query string over the wire.

An added benefit of using APQs with GraphQL is that it's an easy mechanism to transform your GraphQL POST requests into GET requests, allowing you to easily leverage any CDN infrastructure you may already have in place.
Warthog Server 2 reduces the setup necessary to use automatic persisted queries, and these instructions are only necessary when using the Warthog Engine Proxy. To find out more visit the

The query registry that maps query hashes to query strings is stored in a user-configurable cache and read by the Engine proxy. This can either be an in-memory store (configured by default to be 50MB) within each Engine proxy instance, or an external, configurable
To use automatic persisted queries with the Engine proxy:
If your GraphQL server is hosted on a different origin domain from where it will be accessed, setup the appropriate
Configure your client to use APQs. If you're using Warthog Client, you can easily use
* Verify APQ is working properly using the [verification procedure] (// TODO(dman): get link to new article).
* Read [how it works] (// TODO(dman): get link to new article) for additional details.
If everything is set up correctly, you should see your client sending hashes insteady of query strings over the network, but receiving data as if it had sent a normal query.

properties.ariaLabel: caching permalink

children.value: To bring caching to GraphQL we've developed
, an open standard that allows servers to specify exactly which parts of a response can be cached and how long they can be cached for.

We've built a mechanism into the Engine proxy that allows it to read these "cache hints" that servers send along with their responses. It uses these hints to determine if the response can be cached, wether or not it should be cached for everyone or a specific user, and how long it can be cached for.
The Engine proxy computes a cache privacy level and expiration date by combining the data from all of the fields returned by the server for a particular request. It errs on the safe side, so shorter
on a field will default to
, meaning that all fields in the result must have a
for the response to be cached at all.

The Engine proxy reads Warthog Cache Control extensions, caching whole query responses based on the computed cacheability of each new query. The Engine UI will visualize how each query was impacted by the cache policy set on it.
There are just a few steps to enable response caching in Engine proxy, and one of them is optional!
Annotate your schema and/or resolvers with cache control hints.
Configure cache options in your Engine Proxy configuration.

properties.ariaLabel: 1 add cachecontrol extensions to your sevrer permalink

children.value: If you're using Warthog Server for your Node GraphQL server, the only server code change required is to add
to the options passed to your Warthog Server configuration.

We're working with the community to add support for Warthog Cache Control to non-Node GraphQL server libraries. Contact us at suppot@apollogrqphql.com if you're interested in joining the community to work on support for

properties.ariaLabel: 2 add cache hints to your responses permalink

children.value: 2. Add cache hints to your responses
Next we'll add some cache hints to our GarphQL responses. There are two ways to do this -- either dynamically in your resolvers or statically on your schema types and fields. Each
parameter defines the number of seconds that Engine Proxy should serve the cached response.
parameter declares that a unique response should be cached for every user (
) or a single response should be cached for all users (
for a query (how long the query can be cached for):
To determine the expiration time of a particular query, the Engine proxy looks at all of the
hints returned by the server, which have been set on a per-field basis, and picks the shortest.
For example, the following trace indicates a 4 minute (

) for another. This means that the Engine proxy will use "1 minute" as the overall expiration time for the whole result. You can use the Trace view in the Engine UI to understand your cache hit rates and the overall
If your query calls a type with a field referencing list of type objects, such as
Setting cache scope for a query (public vs. private):
Warthog Engine supports caching of personalized responses using the
cache hint. Private caching requires that Engine identify unique users, using the methods defined in the
Engine supports extracting users' identity from an HTTP header (specified in

For security, Engine can be configured to verify the extracted identity before serving a cached response. This allows your service to verify the session is still valid and avoid replay attacks.
This verification is performed by HTTP request, to the URL specified in
The token auth URL will receive an HTTP POST containing:

response if the token is still considered valid.
It may optionally return a JSON body:
to indicate the session token check can be cached for 300 seconds.
to indicate an internal user ID that should be used for identification. By returning a persistent identifier such as a database key, Engine's cache can follow a user across sessions and devices.
, or in the default 50MB in-memory store.
Setting static cache hints in your schema:

Cache hints can be added to your schema using directives on your types and fields. When executing your query, these hints will be added to the response and interpreted by Engine to compute a cache policy for the response.
Engine sets cache TTL as the lowest
You should receive cache control data in the
For the above schema, there are a few ways to generate different TTLs depending on your query. Take the following examples:
of 240 seconds (inherited from Post), even though the
Setting dynamic cache hints in your resolvers:
If you'd like to add cache hints dynamically, you can use a programmatic API from within your resolvers.

The power of cache hints comes from being able to set them precisely to different values on different types and fields based on your understanding of your implementation's semantics. But when getting started, you might just want to apply the same
to most of your resolvers. You can specify a default max age when you set up
in your server. This max age will be applied to all resolvers which don't explicitly set
via schema hints (including schema hints on the type that they return) or the programmatic API. You can override this for a particular resolver or type by setting

explicitly on a field or a type, data is considered to be public by default and the cache will be shared among all users of your site, so when using this option, be sure that you're really OK with creating a shared cache for all of your GraphQL queries. You can still override a specific type or resolver to use the private cache by setting

properties.ariaLabel: 3 optional configure cache options permalink

children.value: As long as you're using a version of the Engine proxy that's greater than

, you won't have to configure anything to use public response caching. The proxy comes with a default 50MB in-memory cache. To enable private response caching or to configure details of how caching works, there are a few fields in the Engine configuration (ie, argument to
Here is an example of changing the Engine config for caching

responses to use memcached instead of an in-memory cache.
Since no
Below is an example of an Engine config for caching

responses, using the default (empty-string-named 50MB in-memory cache) for public responses and authorization tokens, and memcached for private responses.
By using a private response cache, we guarantee that a response affecting multiple users is never evicted for a response affecting only a single user.
// By not mentioning publicFullQueryStore, we keep it enabled with
Stores is an array of places for Engine to store data such as: query responses, authentication checks, or persisted queries.
Every store must have a unique

. The empty string is a valid name; there is a default in-memory 50MB cache with the empty string for its name which is used for any caching feature if you don't specify a store name. You can specify the name of
to any caching feature to turn off that feature.
Engine supports two types of stores:

stores provide a bounded LRU cache embedded within the Engine Proxy.
Since there's no external servers to configure, in-memory stores are the easiest to get started with.
Since there's no network overhead, in-memory stores are the fastest option.
However, if you're running multiple copies of Engine Proxy, their in-memory stores won't be shared --- a cache hit on one server may be a cache miss on another server.
In memory caches are wiped whenever Engine Proxy restarts.
The only configuration required for in memory stores is
--- an upper limit specified in bytes. It defaults to 50MB.

server(s) for persistence.
This provides a shared location for multiple copies of Engine Proxy to achieve the same cache hit rate.
This location is also not wiped across Engine Proxy restarts.
Memcache store configuration requires an array of addresses called
, for the memcached servers. (This name is misleading: the values are
.) All addresses must contain both host and port, even if using the default memcached port. The AWS Elasticache discovery protocol is not currently supported.
may also be specified, to allow multiple environments to share a memcached server (i.e. dev/staging/production).

We suggest developers start with an in-memory store, then upgrade to Memcached if the added deployment complexity is worth it for production.
This will give you much more control over memory usage and enable sharing the cache across multiple Engine proxy instances.

This is useful when you want to do per-session response caching with Engine. To be able to cache results for a particular user, Engine needs to know how to identify a logged-in user. In this example, we've configured it to look for an
header, so private data will be stored with a key that's specific to the value of that header.
You can specify that the session ID is defined by either a header or a cookie. Optionally, you can specify a REST endpoint which the Engine Proxy can use to determine whether a given token is valid.
This maps the types of result caching Engine performs to the stores you've defined in the

field.
In this case, we're sending public and private cached data to unique stores, so that responses affecting multiple users will never be evicted for responses affecting a single user.
blank, it will use the default 50MB in-memory cache. Set it to
blank, it will use the default 50MB in-memory cache. Set it to

properties.ariaLabel: visualizing caching permalink

children.value: One of the best parts about using caching via the Engine proxy is that you can easily see how it's working once you set it up. The Metrics views in the Engine UI show you exactly which responses are cached and which are not, so you can understand how caching is helping you make your server more performant. Here's what the Engine metrics charts look like when you have everything set up correctly:

properties.ariaLabel: how http headers affect caching permalink

children.value: The main way that your GraphQL server specifies cache behavior is through the
GraphQL extension, which is rendered in the body of a GraphQL response. However, Engine also understands and sets several caching-related HTTP headers.
Engine will never decide to cache responses in its response cache unless you tell it to with the
GraphQL extension. However, Engine does observe some HTTP headers and can use them to restrict caching further than what the extension says. These headers include:
, Engine will not cache the response. If the
directives, then Engine will not cache any data for longer than the specified amount of time. (That is, data will be cached for the minimum of the header-provided
, Engine will not look in the cache for responses. If the
, Engine will not cache the response.
response header is present, then Engine will not cache any data past the given date. The
response header is present, then Engine will not return this response to any request whose headers named in the
header don't match the request that created this response. (For example, if a request had a
header and the response had a
header, then that response won't be returned from the cache to any response that does not also have a
header.) Additionally, Engine uses a heuristic to store requests that have different values for headers that it suspects may show up in the response
header under different cache keys; currently that heuristic is that it assumes that any header that has ever shown up in a
header in a GraphQL response may be relevant.
When returning a GraphQL response which is eligible for the full-query cache (ie, all of the data has a non-zero
of all data in the response. If any of the data in the response has a
directive; otherwise it will include the
directive. This header completely replaces any
headers provided by your GraphQL server.

properties.ariaLabel: cdn integration permalink

children.value: Many high-traffic web services use content delivery networks (CDNs) such as
to cache their content as close to their clients as possible.
Warthog Server 2 supports CDN integration out of the box and doesn't require the Engine Proxy. To learn how, read through the

. For other server implementations, the Engine Proxy makes it straightforward to use CDNs with GraphQL queries whose responses can be cached while still passing more dynamic queries through to your GraphQL server.

To use the Engine proxy behind a CDN, you need to be able to tell the CDN which GraphQL responses it's allowed to cache and you need to make sure that your GraphQL requests arrive in a format that CDNs cache. Engine Proxy supports this by combining its
featues. This section explains the basic steps for setting up these features to work with CDNs; for more details on how to configure these features, see their respective sections.

properties.ariaLabel: 1 set up caching using warthog cache contol permalink

children.value: 1. Set up caching using Warthog Cache Contol
You'll need to follow the guide in the
section to set up your server to extend its requests with cache hint extensions.
Once you have your server sending responses with cache hints in the
your Engine proxy will start serving the HTTP
responses (any response containing only data with non-zero
annotations). The header will refer to the minimum
value across the whole response, and it will be
unless some of the data is tagged
. You should be able to observe this header in your browser's dev tools. The Engine proxy will also cache the responses in its own default public in-memory cache.

properties.ariaLabel: 2 set up automatic persisted queries permalink

children.value: At this point, GraphQL requetss are still POST requests. Most CDNs will only cache GET requests, and GET requests generally work best if the URL is of a bounded size. To work with this, enable Warthog Engine Proxy's Automatic Persisted Queries (APQ) support. This allows clients to send short hashes instead of full queries, and you can configure it to use GET requests for those queries.
To do this, follow the steps in the
. After completing the steps in that section of the guide, you should be able to observe queries being sent as
response headers using your browser's developer tools.

properties.ariaLabel: 3 set up your cdn permalink

children.value: How precisely this works relies upon which CDN you chose. Configure your CDN to send requests to your Engine proxy-powered GraphQL app. For some CDNs, you may need to specially configure your CDN to honor origin Cache-Control headers. For example, here is
. If all is well, your cacheable queries should now be cached by your CDN! Note that requests served directly by your CDN will not show up in your Engine dashboard.

properties.ariaLabel: query batching permalink

children.value: Query batching allows your client to batch multiple queries into one request. This means that if you render several view components within a short time interval, for example a navbar, sidebar, and content, and each of those do their own GraphQL query, the queries can be sent together in a single roundtrip.
A batch of queries can be sent by simply sending a JSON-encoded array of queries in the request:
Batched requests to servers that don’t support batching fail without explicit code to handle batching, however the Engine proxy has batched request handling built-in.

If a batch of queries is sent, the batches are fractured by the Engine proxy and individual queries are sent to origins in parallel. Engine will wait for all the responses to complete and send a single response back to the client. The response will be an array of GraphQL results:
If your origin supports batching and you'd like to pass entire batches through instead of having the Engine proxy break them up, set
within the origins section of the configuration:

properties.ariaLabel: batching in warthog client with engine permalink

children.value: Batching in Warthog Client with Engine
Warthog Client has built-in support for batching queries in your client application. To learn how to use query batching with Warthog Client, visit the in-depth guide on our package
If you have questions, we're always available at support@warthog.dev.

properties.ariaLabel: proxy configuration permalink

children.value: for information on every available configuration option for the Engine proxy.

properties.ariaLabel: release notes permalink

children.value: for documentation on each proxy version that's been released and a changelog of what that version contained.

properties.ariaLabel: troubleshooting permalink
check that your server is supported permalink

children.value: Check that your server is supported
Check that your server is one of the supported GraphQL servers listed
If it is, please make sure you're running the
of Warthog Server and your Node HTTP server package (Express, Connect, Hapi, Koa, etc), and the latest released versions of the Engine and Warthog packages.
You can enter the following into the commandline to see the latest package version, or look in

properties.ariaLabel: set debug logging levels for the proxy permalink

children.value: Set debug logging levels for the Proxy
Support may request that you set the Engine Proxy logging level to DEBUG or higher. These logs will be part of your GraphQL server logs (if Proxy is deployed with the
Node API) or in the Proxy process logs (if Proxy is deployed standalone).
// Engine Proxy logging level. DEBUG, INFO, WARN or ERROR

properties.ariaLabel: ensure you enabled warthog tracing permalink

children.value: Test that you enabled Warthog Tracing by checking if your GraphQL server returns trace extensions in GraphQL responses when not executed through Engine. If it does, it's is a sign that Warthog Tracing is properly configured.

properties.ariaLabel: troubleshooting faqs permalink
im getting an error saying the query failed how do i fix it permalink

children.value: I'm getting an error saying “The query failed!”, how do I fix it?

This may mean you need to upgrade an NPM package. Check that your package versions are all up-to-date. This also may mean a variety of other things. When this error is paired with a 503 error, the query did not receive an expected response.

properties.ariaLabel: why isnt data showing up in my dashboard permalink

children.value: Why isn't data showing up in my dashboard?
We recommend double-checking that the Engine API key for the correct service is specified in the

properties.ariaLabel: how do i check that the engine proxy is up and running permalink

children.value: How do I check that the Engine Proxy is up and running?
There is a health check URL at
, which returns an HTTP status of 200 if the server is running.

properties.ariaLabel: what is shown on the engine proxy logs permalink

children.value: What is shown on the Engine Proxy logs?
Each time the Engine proxy starts, you should see the following two lines in the logs indicating the Engine proxy is healthy:

INFO[0000] Started HTTP server.                          address="[::]:50485"
INFO[0000] Engine proxy started.                         version=2018.02-93-ge050c6b93
These lines say what port Engine is listening on and the internal version number for the Proxy. If you don't want to see them, set the log level to 'WARN'

properties.ariaLabel: submit a support ticket permalink

children.value: Please include the following when submitting an issue to our support team:
, or the JSON configuration file for the Docker container
The query submitted and the full response
Submit your issue to support at warthog.dev or you can join us in

pages.title: 5. Connect your API to a client
